title: Pamięć gatunku a nowe idee we współczesnym polskim koncercie fortepianowym. Aleksander Nowak – Król kosmosu znika. Koncert na orkiestrę, nici i fortepian

otherTitles.title: Genre Memory and New Ideas in the Contemporary Polish Piano Concerto: Aleksander Nowak’s King of the Cosmos Disappears. Concerto for Orchestra, Threads and Piano

abstracts.content: The musical genres that the avant-garde of the 1960s and 1970s rejected as nothing more than a set of time-honoured rules, continue to inspire contemporary composers in their exploration of new forms of musical language. Such an affinity is present in numerous piano concertos written by Polish composers at the turn of the 21st century. The article presents the results of research and analysis in relation to the composition King of the Cosmos Disappears. Concerto for Orchestra, Threads and Piano by Aleksander Nowak, an intriguing example of the piano concerto genre in the oeuvre of a representative of the ‘middle generation’ of contemporary Polish composers. A number of innovative ideas used in the composition concern both the treatment of the core principles of the genre and the approach to the piano part.

title: Od młodzieńczego rozmachu ku neoklasycznej elegancji. Fortepianowe juwenilia Zygmunta Mycielskiego ze zbioru Szkice kompozycyjne 1927

otherTitles.title: From Youthful Enthusiasm to Neoclassical Elegance: Zygmunt Mycielski’s Piano Juvenilia from the Collection ‘Szkice kompozycyjne 1927’

abstracts.content: The Zygmunt Mycielski Archive is housed in the National Library of Poland in Warsaw. One of the volumes in this collection is a draft signed by the composer, entitled Sketches of Composition 1927. It contains early musical pieces by Zygmunt Mycielski: songs, pieces for piano and chamber music. They were written between 1927 and 1938, first in Wiśniowa and Kraków, then in Paris during Mycielski’s studies with Paul Dukas and Nadia Boulanger, and after returning to Poland, in Vilnius and Bukowina Tatrzańska. Interpreted with the help of letters to mother Maria Mycielska née Szembek, they allow us to reconstruct the creative process, informal instructions from Karol Szymanowski, and learn about the young artist’s preferences.

title: Scherzo jako organowa forma improwizowana. Skrótowa analiza wybranych autorskich przykładów muzycznych w kontekście wykonawczym

otherTitles.title: Scherzo as an Improvised Organ Form. A Brief Analysis of Selected Original Musical Examples in a Performance Context

abstracts.content: Organ improvisation remains linked to symphonic music, which has inspired performers to search for an attractive sound, and to shape works based on formal patterns established over the centuries. When improvising virtuoso organ forms, the individual characteristics of the organist-improviser, such as speed of decision-making, motor coordination and ergonomics in the playing technique, as well as musical imagination, play a key role. The shape of the improvised organ symphonic scherzo is influenced by factors related to a thorough knowledge of the musical elements and the ability to distinguish and define the elements of a given style or musical language. Also crucial here is the degree of technical preparation in keyboard and pedal playing. Advanced works from the piano repertoire remain the appropriate model and area of inspiration for organists to improvise virtuosic forms. An analysis of the recorded scherzos provided a glimpse into the formal course and a general definition of the means of performance. The author hopes that an analytical view of improvised organ pieces will enable young students of music, interested in practising this complex art of immediate music-making on the instrument, to go through the creative process and increase the artistic value of their works. This is particularly important in the context of a marked increase in interest in the art of improvisation that we are seeing today in church music circles and among young organ virtuosos.

title: Brzmienie chóralne – przypadek, czy świadome działanie?

otherTitles.title: Choral sound - an accident or a conscious effort?

abstracts.content: Changes in the contemporary choral sound are a fact. The sound of Polish choirs is becoming part of a broader, worldwide perspective, imitating the universal timbre of excellent professional choirs. The author tries to pinpoint the reasons for this phenomenon, and to show the global trends and influences in this regard. Awareness of the changes allows the development of effective tools in the workshop of the choirmaster and professionalization of activities in working with contemporary choral compositions.
